_prev_prog_3.Description: The Steuben Foods Plant's Prevention Program is composed of the following elements, which are all part of the Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  This program follows the requirements set forth in 29 CFR 1910.119:  1) Employees participate in the elements of this safety and release prevention program wherever possible; 2) Training is provided for operators and maintenance personnel; 3) Process Safety Information (PSI) is maintained on ammonia hazards and the refrigeration system; 4) A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the refrigeration system was conducted and is periodically reviewed to ensure adequacy of controls; 5) The Mechanical Integrity program ensures the system continues to operate as designed; 6) Operating and Maintenance procedures provide operators and maintenance staff the information necessary to safely operate and maintain the system; 7) Contractors working on or near the refrigeration system are selected for safety performance, and are briefed on the hazards and safety requirements of the job; 8) Hot Work Permits are required whenever welding, cutting, grinding or other activities are conducted that could generate sparks and start a fire; 9) The Management of Change (MOC) program requires that the impact of changes to the refrigeration system be evaluated and approved prior to the work being conducted; 10) Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) are conducted prior to restart of the system after modifications to ensure that impacts of the change are addressed; 11) Incident investigations are conducted for incidents involving ammonia releases and near misses that endanger employees or the public, if such an incident were to occur; 12) Compliance Audits are conducted every three years to ensure that the prevention program is meeting its objectives; 13) Emergency Planning and Response ensures that employees and emergency personnel are prepared to respond to an ammonia release in accordance with the plant's emergency plan and that notifications are made to designated points of contact at local, state, and federal levels depending on the extent of the release.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
I.   ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY POLICIES

     Steuben Foods recognizes management's responsibility in protecting it's employees, equipment, property, and the environment. The safety and health of all personnel are very important.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the facility.

     The Steuben Foods PSM/RMP program assigns and documents the specific responsibilities for developing, implementing and  integrating the OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP standards into its safety program.  The PSM/RMP program focuses attention on "Making PSM/RMP the way we manage our ammonia based refrigeration system" rather than a project we expect to complete and put on the shelf when the fileing date has passed.

     Steuben Foods believes that Employee participation is the key to a successful program.  Operating level employees, particularly the Maintenance Manager and the Refrigeration System Operators, have been deeplly involved and they paarticipate actively in the safe operation of the  Steuben Facility in Elma, New York.

     The Steuben Foods Emergency Response Program has been developed with the complete cooperation and support of the Elma Fire Department.  All Steuben Foods employees have received documented emergency response training.


II.  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

     Steuben Foods is a Manufacturer of Aseptic dairy products.
     The refrigeration system contains Anhydrous Ammonia which is recognized as an Accutely Hazardous Material by both OSHA and the EPA.. 
      

III.  SUMMARY OF WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Dispersion cloud modeling studies have been performed as required by PSM/RMP regulations and the information developed has been used in the preparation of the Technical Studies and Reports that are also required.

IV.   DESCRIPTION OF THE STEUBEN FOODS ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

     Steuben Foods conducts an annual PSM/RMP im

plementation progress audit of the entire PSM/RMP prograr to identify strengths and weaknesses and make improvements.  Steuben Foods considers the PSM/RMP manuals to be "living" documents that must be updated and revised regularly to maintain their viability.

     Steuben Foods emphasizes and insists on  "employee participation" from the refrigeration system operators in all aspects of the developent, implementation, and integration of their PSM/RMP program.

     Steuben Foods provides a comprehensive, computer based, user friendly training program with "one-on-one" teacher involvement in specific training modules for each ammonia refrigeration employee.

     Steuben Foods maintains a pro-active "open-door" policy toward neighbors and concerned community citizens.  Facility tours and risk management discussions are scheduled and conducted upon written request.

V.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENTAL RELEASE HISTORY

     There have been no releases of ammonia at Steuben Foods that resulted in an injury, or that had an off-site impact, or that resulted in significant property damage either on-site or off-site.

VI.  Emergency Response Program

     Steuben Foods conducts an annual training and response exercise with the Elma Fire Department to practice, train and update the Emergency Response Program.

     Facility employees have been trained to respond to accidental ammonia release in a defensive manner.  The site emergency plan has been coordinated with the community emergency plan under the jurisdiction of the Local Elma Fire Department.

VII.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

      Steuben Foods recognizes that even good PSM/RMP Programs require constant attention and improvement.  The PSM/RMP program is considered to be a set of "living" documents and procedures that will require constant attention, development, and revision before "Safety" truly becomes "second nature".

     Steuben Foods expects to improve PSM/RMP and safety performance by emphasizing the following e

lements of their PSM/RMP Program:

 (1)   EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:  Employee Participation is the "Key" to a successful program. Ammonia Process Managers and Operators have been deeply involved in developing and updating the Standard Operating Procedures, and performing the documented Preventive Maintenance Inspections.

(2)    EXPANCED USE OF THEIR PSM/RMP WEB-SITE:  The Steuben Foods PSM/RMP Program is:  (a) computer based,  (b) user friendly,  (c) includes "one-on-one" involvement with specified and qualified trainers,  (d) written to minimize paperwork and maximize documentation, and  (e) written to be understood and used by both Ammonia Managers and Ammonia Process Operators.  The web-site makes all information developed by the PSM/RMP Program available to all employees who have a User Name and Password.  All Steuben Foods Refrigeration System Operators have an assigned User Name and Password. 

(3)  PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS: All recommendations developed during the Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) were designed to improve the safety performance of the Ammonia Refrigeration System.  Steuben Foods has evaluated each PHA recommendation.  Each recommendation has been installed and will reduce the possibility of a release and/or mitigate the consequences of an unintentional release.

(4) AUDITS:   Programs are audited Tri-Annually as required by the OSHA PSM regulation to improve Safety Performance as well as to verify compliance with the PSM/RMP Regulations. 

(5)  STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES:  SOP's are certified annually to be current and correct.  They are revised as often as necessary to keep them current and correct.

(6)  TRAINING:  Orientation Training (both classroom and On-the-Job) is provided employees before Ammonia related work assignments are given.  Renewal training, including documented training tests are provided annually.
